DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed in Quiet Trading
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices rose slightly today amid news of new export business while other grain and soybean futures were unchanged to lower in early trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. The Agriculture Department announced this morning it had accepted two bids from exporters to cover sales of nearly 110,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat to Iraq at subsidized prices. The corn, oat and soybean markets were nearly unchanged in extremely quiet trading with many traders absent because of the sub-zero weather in Chicago or because of the upcoming holiday weekend. ``I really don't know when I've ever seen it this slow,'' said John Frazier, an executive vice president of Balfour Maclaine Corp. on the trading floor. The markets were scheduled to close at noon central time and will not reopen until Tuesday. In early trading, wheat futures were } cent to 1\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.14 a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to \ cent lower with March at $2.38{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent lower with March at $1.54\ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 2 cents lower with January at $5.73{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were narrowly mixed in quiet trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .02 cent to .15 cent lower with February at 76.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .18 cent higher with January at 84.70 cents a pound; live hogs were .42 cent lower to .15 cent higher with February at 49.05 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .02 cent lower to .48 cent higher with February at 50 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled higher on Thursday.
